vulnerabilities.title: Missing Authentication
vulnerabilities.description: The MCP server at http://localhost:3000 does not require authentication. Any client can connect and access all available tools and resources.
vulnerabilities.remediation:
Implement authentication mechanism such as:
- API keys
- OAuth 2.0
- Mutual TLS (mTLS)
- JWT tokens

vulnerabilities.title: Unencrypted Connection
vulnerabilities.description: The MCP server at http://localhost:3000 does not use TLS/SSL encryption. All communication is transmitted in plaintext, allowing attackers to intercept sensitive data including credentials and API responses.
vulnerabilities.remediation:
Enable TLS/SSL encryption:
- Use HTTPS instead of HTTP
- Install valid SSL certificate
- Configure TLS 1.2 or higher
- Disable weak cipher suites

vulnerabilities.title: Dangerous Tools Exposed Without Authorization
vulnerabilities.description: The MCP server exposes 2 potentially dangerous tools without proper authorization controls. Combined with missing authentication, these tools can be abused for system compromise.
vulnerabilities.remediation:
Implement proper authorization:
- Role-based access control (RBAC)
- Principle of least privilege
- Input validation for all tools
- Audit logging for tool usage

vulnerabilities.title: Default Port Configuration
vulnerabilities.description: The MCP server is running on a default port (3000). This makes it easier for attackers to discover and target the server.
vulnerabilities.remediation:
Change to a non-standard port:
- Use a random high port (>10000)
- Update firewall rules accordingly
- Document the port change

vulnerabilities.title: Version Information Disclosure
vulnerabilities.description: The server discloses its version (1.0.0), which can help attackers identify known vulnerabilities in that specific version.
vulnerabilities.remediation:
Minimize information disclosure:
- Remove or obfuscate version headers
- Use generic error messages
- Keep software updated regardless
